Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Frameworks for Dynamic Reserve Policies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop a new paradigm for the determination of reserve requirements for either day-ahead unit commitment (UC) models or reliability UC models to maintain a reliable electric power system. Specifically, this work will 1) develop novel mathematical programming frameworks for the determination of reserve zones and reserve levels embedded in unit commitment models; 2) develop mathematical frameworks that adaptively determine reserve requirements for various reliability standards; 3) embed dynamic reserve policies inside stochastic programming algorithms in order to improve scalability and solution quality; 4) compare the techniques to existing reserve rules as well as stochastic programming techniques; 5) validate the concepts by demonstrating improvements in reliability, economic efficiency, and scalability; 6) validate these techniques by examining their ability to facilitate the integration and management of high levels of variable generation (renewable) resources.

If successful, the mathematical frameworks for reserve policies will lead to improvements in electric power systems operations and planning by improving efficiency and systems reliability, with a reduction in grid outages. This framework will also improve the ability to manage renewable resources and, thus, allow for higher levels of variable renewable resources, which will help reduce emissions and it will facilitate the development of a sustainable economy for energy independence and security. The process to balance reserve policies with stochastic programming algorithms will facilitate the integration and adoption of stochastic programming in electric power systems. The mathematical models and polyhedral studies developed will also contribute to large scale network flow or scheduling problems with uncertainties and reliability standards, e.g., transportation systems and telecommunication systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The US electric grid, and many national and regional grids globally, are experiencing high penetration levels of variable and uncertain renewable resources, such as wind and solar. Certain regions have established goals to achieve at least 50% of electric power generation from renewable resources. With high penetration levels of such semi-controllable resources, existing methods to manage uncertainty in power generation scheduling problems do not provide for adequate reliability and economic efficiency. Existing methods often result in over-commitment of the very generation resources that the renewables attempt to replace; fossil-fuel resources are committed to compensate for the variability and uncertainty of renewable resources by providing ancillary services (reserves). The increased reserve requirements for mitigating uncertainty imposed by renewable integration are compounded by stringent constraints on the placement of such reserves due to transmission limitations, which is exacerbated by the remote location of wind and concentrated solar resources. Furthermore, since the electric power industry is roughly 300 billion dollars a year (for the USA alone), there is a need for new optimization technologies that can efficiently manage renewable resources. As a result, innovative optimization techniques are needed in decision support tools used in the electric power sector.

 

This research focuses on the determination of dynamic reserve policies. Existing methods to determine how much backup capacity to maintain to compensate for unplanned outages and fluctuations in renewable resources are currently based on rule-of-thumb approaches. Such ad-hoc approaches are inefficient at determining the quantity of reserve needed and especially the location of the reserve. The existing methods are also seen as being static as they primarily do not reflect changes in the operational state of the system, which dictates the real-time delivery of reserves and, hence, the locational aspect of choosing reserve. Existing methods also inadequately reflect the uncertainty itself, which dictates the quantity of reserves that are needed. Such methods are also infrequently updated. Reserve zones are an example of such rule-of-thumb approaches, where a region of the system is identified and required to hold a particular amount of reserves. However, such reserve zones are static and are largely determined by aspects that are not related to operational conditions and instead they are related to utility, state, or geographical boundaries.

 

The primary means to solve this problem is to update existing electric energy market auction models to transition from a deterministic program to a stochastic program. Such stochastic programs can account for uncertainty directly. While stochastic programs can determine the optimal location and quantity of the needed reserves to ensure a reliable supply of electricity, they come with two fundamental challenges. First, stochastic programs are much more computationally challenging. Second, the electric energy markets and the existing market settlement rules would have to be redesigned. While the first challenge is a technical challenge being attacked by many researchers, the second challenge relates more so to practical market barriers and has received far less attention. This research tackles both challenges. This work has produced a methodology, dynamic reserve policies, to update reserve requirements for both the forward and spot electric energy markets. Dynamic reserve policies can be viewed as determining the appropriate cluster of generators, or loads, necessary to supply a determined quantity of reserves.

 

The approach makes theoretical advances by leveraging data mining techniques to develop model approximations that enable deterministic mathematical programs to produce more reliable solutions without having to explicitly model the uncertainties, i.e., rely on a stochastic programming formulation. While the proposed approach can be used in replace of stochastic programs, the research also shows that it can be combined with stochastic programs as a complement in order to reduce solution time. The proposed dynamic reserves approach is also practical as existing electric energy market designs and market settlement rules do not need to be redesigned for the proposed changes. The proposed approach is also easier to solve than stochastic programs alone, which is critical since such market management systems for both forward and spot markets have tight time limitations.

 

The proposed changes would impact many different applications in the electric power sector. While the focus of the research is on the energy management systems and market management systems of forward and spot markets, the technology can also facilitate other decision support tools for operational and planning problems. By improving the ability to manage renewable resources, more renewable resources can be integrated into the electric power grid, which will facilitate the development of a sustainable economy for energy independence and security. The mathematical models and polyhedral studies developed also contribute to large scale network flow and scheduling problems with uncertainties and reliability standards, e.g., transportation systems and tele-communication systems.
